simone

Ripskar

I here allot of bad press about Roam.
 
 Whats you take.

 
 Scrambled Babel-fish alert...
 People are people, some good, some bad, but mostly ugly.
 Rome gets pretty boring after Trajan.
 The best bit are the Punic Wars, though there are other highlights such as Celts defeating Rome and demanding their king's weight in gold.
 The Roman invasions of Britain are important here.
 European History tends to revolve around Rome in one way or other. 
 My own take is that what happened, happened.
 Was Britain permanently damaged by being a Roman colony? 
 Was Roman civilisation the best thing before sliced bread?
 I don't think either question really has that much relevance, too much of that is subjective.

post_info.post_title: Oh well way to go sweetheart, now I know your a girl.

johnhanks

Whether or not Christianity played a part in the downfall of the Roman empire...

 
 The opposite relation is more likely. It's been argued that promoting a religion that stresses the merits of poverty and self-denial was an astute move for Constantine at a time of imperial decline.
Ripskar

What is the religious take?
 
 Are you religious?

 
 I'm Secular Agnostic.
 
 Gibbon can be interpreted as suggesting that the Christians weakened Rome before it fell. In fighting and political ambition were definately factors.
 Religion's role becomes more pronounced after the fall because they burnt the philosophical works etc. and didn't copy anything other than the Bible.
 Some of the Greek works only survive because a monk used the paper to copy bible sections onto.
Monster

I'm Secular Agnostic.
 
 Gibbon can be interpreted as suggesting that the Christians weakened Rome before it fell. In fighting and political ambition were definately factors.
 Religion's role becomes more pronounced after the fall because they burnt the philosophical works etc. and didn't copy anything other than the Bible.
 Some of the Greek works only survive because a monk used the paper to copy bible sections onto.

 
 weakened Rome before it fell?
 
 How.
Ripskar

Gibbon suggests that Rome power was based on brutality, Christianity however fostered a growing notion of meekness and turning the other cheek.
 Groups that would have been erased form existance before were left to grow in power.
 He also refers to collapse of the previous Roman theology; The Emperor was a God and his were the words of the Gods. When Constantine converted and started proclaiming monotheism this rather threw the system into confusion.
 
 More important than all that however is what Gibbon says regarding the Vigin Birth.
 At one time the Church said that Jesus divinity was based on his being without sin. This contradicted their teachings regarding the stain of original sin, so they added the doctrine of immaculate conception which was ripped off from the story of Romulus and Remus.
sanguinekane

The opposite relation is more likely. It's been argued that promoting a religion that stresses the merits of poverty and self-denial was an astute move for Constantine at a time of imperial decline.

 
 Constantine didn't do much to promote Christianity however, the man wasn't even a real Christian, he just saw the Christian god as a nother diety to worship. Sure, he believe that diety may have been above all the others, but he was still a pagan, he even continued to put Sol Invictus on his coins and promote only pagans to the top offices in the empire. 
 
 I'd be more inclined to say that while the followers of Christianity as a whole did not intend or want to be a contributing cause to the fall of the empire, there were definitely destabalising elements (towards the Romans at least) within the belief at the time.
